title: Fixing Fragments and Run-Ons
learning_objectives: Recognize fragments, run-ons, and comma splices
Use punctuation correctly to join clauses
Avoid traps that mimic spoken English but break grammar rules

content.title: Sentence Boundaries
content.subtitle: Fragments and run-ons
points: Ensure proper use of conjunctions and punctuation

content.title: Common Pitfalls
content.explanation: Spoken English often accepts fragments and run-ons, but SAT requires formal grammar.
content.example: Trap: 'She loves books, she reads daily.' Correct: 'She loves books, and she reads daily.'

content.title: 3-Step Process
steps: Step 1: Identify subject + verb ‚Üí is it complete?
Step 2: If two clauses, ensure correct connector or punctuation.
Step 3: Eliminate options that mimic speech but violate rules.

content.title: Apply the Strategy
content.question: Which choice fixes the error? 'The concert was exciting, people cheered loudly.'
choices: The concert was exciting, people cheered loudly.
The concert was exciting; people cheered loudly.
The concert was exciting people cheered loudly.
The concert was exciting people, cheered loudly.
content.explanation: Only B fixes comma splice correctly using semicolon.

content.title: Solution Walkthrough
solution_steps: Two clauses: 'The concert was exciting' + 'people cheered loudly'.
Check B: semicolon joins correctly ‚Üí correct.

content.title: Boundary Mastery
key_points: Fix run-ons with semicolons or conjunctions.
